The wrap is huge so I felt like I was eating layers and layers of it and some of the lamb tasted like it was ... re-microwaved? Kind of crunchy and old-ish. 

Not a re-do.
author: Christine Y.

description:
I usually frequent as many diverse Mediterranean places as I can, The food here was of good quality, I ordered the Chicken Kabob plate. The kabobs were a little on the skimpy side considering the 12$ price for the plate. The one thing that earned this place 1 star in my humble opinion was the service.

When my order came up, I heard the number the waitress did not bother to look at my table and gave my food to the people sitting directly behind me, the guy preparing the food noticed this and went to that table to take the food back and directly handed it to me, during this time the patron had touched the food - i was appalled for one, that this guy had the nerve to just grab the food and offer it to me, secondly when I told him that I did not want something that had been handled by another patron, he indicated she only touched the bread - I asked him are you sure - he then was like ask her... No I don't think so bring me out another plate please.

I do not believe I shall be visiting this establishment again
author: Jorge J.

description:
kebabs, falafels, and latkes mmmm this place is great if you are looking for healthier lunch options.

The chicken kebab salad is delicious and I'd also recommend the falafel wrap or plate as both ares really tasty!

It is a bit on the pricey side but if you have a craving for falafel, this will do it!
author: Christine W.

description: would say 3.5 stars. owner is rather evasive but a good cook. french fries and tahini were solid...overall I thought the quality of the food was great. the ambiance and service needs an upgrade.
author: James B.

description:
Ok. I admit, the guy behind the counter isn't the friendliest. I won't even try to defend him. He's takin' our monehhh & should do so with at least a reluctant smile instead of grunting like he's Kyros, the friendly giant. Except, you know, he's not friendly at all. What happened to friendly ones like Hagrid? 

Anyways, this place is usually a one man operation with a counter immediately to the right where aforementioned Kyros (not his name, I'm sure, but I'll call him that for convenience sake) may or may not acknowledge your existence and not ask what you'd like to have; just tell him and if you're lucky, you'll get a grunt to know that he heard you. 

While the service is lacking, damnit if those magical giant hands don't serve the best falafel wrap I've ever had. That's what my rating is for, and that's what keeps me coming back to the giant's nicely decorated falafel cave.

On the plus side, parking hasn't been a problem for me when I've come , and he does seem to be warming up to me since the last time he managed to at least tell me the soup special, though he could have been talking to the kebab sandwich that he was gazing at and focusing so intently on preparing.
author: Veronica G.

description:
The staff was very kind and the restaurant had a lovely, clean interior.

However, the food was just so-so.  I was expecting more authentic Mediterranean food and this was not that.  The bean salad appeared to be out of a can and very plain.  

I had the bean salad, fattoush, tzazekee and dolmas.  Honestly, the nothing really stood out to me as "man, that sure was good."

It's as if the flavors and ingredients had a lot of potential to be nice and fresh but just fell short of actual follow through.

Though I want to stress again that unlike the other reviews I read, the staff was very helpful and inviting... It's just that the food isn't what I was expecting.  

Given all the opportunities in this city to have authentic Mediterranean food, it doesn't make much sense to opt for only so-so.
author: LauraKatherine L.

description:
For the love of god, eat here!

There's a wait, of course, at lunch time. 

I had the veggie wrap w/ eggplant and the garlic action. No falafel, which has been vouched for as the best in the city. 

What I did have was a Mission sized burrito wrap, filled with deeelicious light and flavorful food. 

Garlic, eggplant, zukes, tomatoes. It's pricey at $8.95, but good!
author: Em L.

description:
My boyfriend and I have been going here for a late night weekend dinner for a few months now and have always had a top-notch experience. I was surprised to see how many folks comment on the owner's lack of good customer service - we've always found him to the friendliest and most accommodating guy who always makes sure we're happy and satisfied.  When it's quiet in the evenings, he even stops by and chats with us and once even gave us a free dessert.  

The food is sooo good here, and to quote an earlier review, an *amazing value* for what you pay.  We always get the fatoush salad, which comes with the most incredible tomatoes, and the succulent lamb kabob -- both are top-notch delicious.  My boyfriend has been going here for years, and also loves the soup, and the fact that its one of the only places to serve Chimay beer.  The beer is always served in beautiful glasses, perfectly polished and spotless, there is always good music playing,  and the ambiance of the place is a creative mix of urban panache with a cool middle-eastern vibe.  

In short, this is a great restaurant -- a solid selection of dishes at good value prices,  with nice ambiance, and good service.
author: Maria R.

description:
This place is horrible - save yourself the trouble and dont go here. I went with my 18 month old and I was told the only place I could sit was by the door. The restaurant was empty, there was no one in there. When I asked why, the guy replied very rudely b/c I have fancy cushions on my chairs.

well guess what I walked right out as my baby is not a monster who will destroy their chairs or cushions or watever. I told all my friends and I guess he wont be getting any business from our circle of friends
author: Moona Z.

description:
Lunchtime lamb shawarma sandwich. Skimpy toppings rolled up with average lamb. I expected something more, considering the trumped up reviews. It's like going on a bad first date. No surprises, no complexity, no hot factor.

**Plus one Faye star for the polite and courteous manager
author: Faye P.

description: My fiance and I went here and the food was delicious, they have great desserts too. We were very impressed with the quality, prices and portions......I give it 5 stars!
author: Jeanne B.

description: Not a good place to go. Service was bad and one of the server, who's a guy, kicked my friends and I out. We ordered food for there and he forced us to have it to go to "make room" for customers. No one was in line and there was no line forming.... Never coming here again and the guy server just rubs me the wrong way
author: Emily S.

description:
Woohoo is right!

I absolutely love this place in every way: the food, the ambience and the service most of all. Ziad is the man!

The babganoush is to die fo and the chicken kabobs are heavenly!

I love love love this place!!!

"I'm just made about Saffron...Saffron's mad about me." :)
author: Johnny R.

description:
Today, I happened to be in the neighborhood for a gallery opening.  My friend and I decided to not eat the food at the opening. I noticed Saffron 685 from across the street.  We walked in and were immediately at ease with the light wood furniture and curry/caramel colored walls and furniture coverings.  
    We both chose the Falafel Wrap.  As we each munched on the most delicious falafel sandwich I have ever had (I've traveled most of the US and have had many flafel sandwiches), I ordered two Turkish coffees.  They were delicious, and blended well with the Falafel wraps.  After eating, and going to the counter to pay.  I had to have a sesame cookie for desert.
     A seductive, more than delicious place to eat.  I look forward to having a kabob for dinner!
author: Patrick B.

description:
I worked across the street from here for 3 months and I never tried it, but last weekend we were looking for a place to eat a snack in between a wedding and the reception and this was the place for it.

Trying to aim for something light, I wanted to have the shawerma naturally because I never eat light, but settled on the latkes which are traditional potato pancakes. Let me tell you, they were sooooooo good. Henry L. and Cindy C. did end up ordering the shawerma plate, so I was lucky enough to sample from it. The lamb was so very tasty. It didn't taste like barn, which is why I normally avoid eating lamb in the first place. 

Everything I tried was pretty good here, and the man who took our order was super friendly. He suggested things for us to have and was very paternal about it. It was cute. Then as we were leaving he gave us some baklava to sample. That also was so crisp with this filo dough. Very good experience all around.
author: Jessica C.

description:
THE OCCASION: Girl-bonding lunch with Jax, July 24, 2009 @ Noon

THE VENUE: Feast for the eyes as well as for the palate. Very hip. Walls painted in Saffron and brick.  Bright colorful pillows placed all over.  You can either sit at the table or on the OVERSIZED PILLOWS ON THE FLOOR.

THE MOOD:  SOMA employees energetic and lively  during a  Friday lunch. Probably looking forward to the weekend. Plenty of tables and not crowded at all. Warm and cozy for dining with friends or eating solo.

THE FOOD:
Common Mediterranean dishes but the FRESHNESS of the ingredients is WHAT SETS  this Mediterranean place APART from the rest.   The dishes are flavorful and light unlike some of the heavily oiled dished I've had at other Mediterranean places in the past. Generous portions on big white plate.

THE SERVICE
You order cafeteria style and they will bring your food to your table. The servers were friendly and efficient.

THE FOOD:
Everything looked so good that my GF and I had a hard time deciding what to get but we ordered:
-2 Orders of MEDITERREAN PLATE: 
Hot and fresh Pita Bread
Hummus
Tabouleh
Mojjadara (lentil and bulgur topped with caramelized onion)  
Fattoush (salad of tomato, mint, cucumber with toasted pita and lemon)

-A side of Tzazekee (cucumber dip)

THE TOPIC: 
A. How  good we are  keeping our promise to have regular girl-bonding lunches.  Will have many more to come.  
B. How we got it so good when we were still single but currentl life is good as well.

THE TAB: $23.00 for 2 happy and well-fed girls (Tax included)
author: Leah E.

description:
This place is extremely quaint and under the radar.  I RARELY see anybody in here when I walk by. (I work down the street).

After forgetting my lunch and reading Yelp, I decided to try my luck here.  I ordered the lamb shawerma and loved every bite!  The lamb was delicious and tender and the shawerma itself was perfectly juicy.  I've had bad experiences with extremely dry shawermas, so this is very important to me. It is a pretty hefty size.

The service was very fast.  This was all I ordered and I was in and out within 10 minutes.  As I sat there I noticed, that the actual restaurant felt new and fresh and extremely clean.  I really respect and like that.
author: Michelle V.

description:
*  The best Lamb Shwermas in town!  
*  Pillow seating on the floor, are you kidding?  It's like I was back in my favorite restaurant in the middle east!
*  Ziad is super friendly.  His conversations definitely round out the total dining experience.  
*  Super busy during lunch, so be patient.  It is worth the wait!
author: R C.

description:
Maybe weekday friendlier?

Yikes...very cold atmosphere just got my nails done next door...don't understand this place...I support my neighborhood - but this guy does not even acknowledged me coming in...i was the only one in the place! 

nasty attitude....
author: Liz D.

description: You people are crazy if you think you can find better Mediterranean food at this price and quality anywhere in SF!  I've been a customer of Saffron 685 for over 8 years and it is still just as good as ever.  Try it again and I guarantee you will love your dining experience!
author: Matthew C.

description:
My friends and I came here on a Saturday night. This place was deserted and I was a little worried. This is definitely one of those places for lunch at work as this place seems to be in the midst of a business park. The food was good. pretty much your typical Mediterranean fare. On Saturday nights it is a one man show.  We walked there from market street. not so much a good idea. 

I had the lamb shawarma which was good. and a side of falafel which was okay. just a little on the crispy side.  i dont live in the area and I dont think it is a must go, but if you are in the area go for it!
author: Grace L.

description:
I was very excited to try this place since I LOVE me some good falafal. The ambiance is great, but the food was only OK and the service was abysmal. 

The back has great couches and the low circle tables with pillows as seats while the front has regular tables. I got the falafal wrap, which surprisingly came with homemade tahini, hummus, eggplant, and lettuce. It was good, but nothing extraordinary. In fact, I think there were only 2 or 3 falafals in the entire thing because of all the other fillings and the lavash was completely dried out. I also had to try the baklava since, well, who can resist baklava? It was also dried out and barely had any honey on it. Not good. 

It was then that I saw the latkes, or potato pancakes for you gentiles. They were huge and chunky and looked amazing. So I bought 2 for lunch the next day. I could hardly wait for lunch the next day and anxiously heated them up in the toaster oven. I wanted to try them naked, without the apple sauce and sour cream that latkes go so well with. Wow. What a disappointment. All I could taste was a mouthful of salt. Then a mouthful of pepper. Lots of seasoning, but no potato. They were barely edible. 

To top it off, the gals behind the counter were pretty miserable. No smile. No nothing. Almost as if we were bothering them just by simply being there. Sorry, Safrron. I'll get my falafal fix somewhere else.
author: Amy B.

description: This place has nice food, but the one guy who works there is so rude.  He's the tall man other people have referred to in their reviews.  He is so arrogant and condescending, just dripping with attitude.  This is the second time I've left the place thinking "what a jerk."  This time it seems he was annoyed because I interrupted his phone call.  I walked in at 3:30 in the afternoon and there were no customers there.  I had to wait to place my order until he was finished with his call.  Then when I finally placed my order he acted like it was a big pain.  This guy needs a new profession -- NOT in a customer-facing role.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Strolled upon this place after massages at Suchada (just around the corner).  It was the only place open so my husband and I decided to check it out.  YUMMY!

We had the Lamb Shawerma and the Meza plate with hummus, falafel and bean salad.  I haven't had Mediterranean food this good since I was in NYC.  There was plenty of tables.  I'd love to come back again.  

I had to take away a star because they do not accept AMEX (my personal card of choice), but other than that -- great service and excellent food!
author: Aura J.

description:
After receiving a very kind message from our server at this place, I am deeply touched and therefore, I must bump this place back up to its well-deserved 4 stars. 

Thank you for the apology and the clarification of how your restaurant works. It truly is a delicious place and because of your hospitality, I hope to come by again sometime soon.
author: Steph W.

description:
The food here is decent.  Not the best, but it's decent.

Here's the rub.  The service is AWFUL.  The worst.  The tall guy with the hat is always rude to me & I've been there a good 20 times. (yes, I'm a glutton for punishment!)  The final straw, though, was when I was told that my group of 4, including my four year old daughter, could not sit on the benches in the back.  When I asked why, I was told that kids are messy.  Please; this is one step up from fast food!  And my kid isn't perfect, but she's pretty clean!

Next time I have a craving for falafel, I will head to Ali Babas in the Mission.
author: Jen K.

description:
I was really impressed by the Falafel Plate. The falafels were very hot/warm at the table too. Browned to perfection - not too crunchy on the outside and the right amount of moist and soft on the inside (typically the falafels I have eaten are overcooked and often hurt the mouth to eat because they've got such a hard shell). The presentation was very nice and clean. My boyfriend and I really enjoyed how fresh the food was and we loved the salad additions, they were delicious. 

The atmosphere was nice; Tastefully decorated and comfortable. 

The staff seemed pretty hard-nosed...by that I mean, I gave the server a brief glance and he was staring me down for a good 5 minutes. Kind of intimidating guy, but he was...moderately polite I suppose.

I am giving it a 4 star rating due to the fact I felt like I was walking egg shells around the server.
author: Sara M.

description:
I signed up for Yelp just now so I could rate this guy.  I've been in this place several times because I like the food and try to ignore the rudeness of the guy.  He will only prepare the plate and the food the way he wants to so don't even bother trying to change anything.  Don't ask for a small side of anything because he will charge you for it.  Don't ask him to do anything he doesn't want to do because he'll tell you that you don't have to eat there.  He really is like the Soup Nazi from Seinfeld.

I hope he comes to his senses soon or some else takes over the customer service part of the business.  The food is decent if you have no place else to go, just know that this guy thinks he's better than you.
author: Monica B.

description:
Really great location and the best chicken shwarma have had the good fortune to eat.  Ziad took a chicken kebob and grilled it over a hot grill and placed the wonderful yummy goodness in my wrap with lots of veggies.

The prices are reasonable and the tsaziki sauce was a cool and refreshing addition to my shwarma.  Staff was super nice.  I hope I have another excuse to come by SOMA sometime soon!
author: Connie P.

description:
The place was unfortunately a huge disappointment and I would highly recommend not to order from Saffron for catering food. I asked for enough food to feed 45 people and what was provided only fed 25 -30. They offer a kebab tray with 12 skewers at $85 and you would think that they would be pretty decent size skewers, but they were puny. It took 2 or 3  to actually fill you up. And when asking how many trays they recommended they said 4 (only to end up bringing us 3) which was insufficient and so expensive. When I called back to let them know there wasn't nearly enough food they wanted to charge me even more to bring another tray. This place is insanely over priced and really not that great. If you want a good restaurant for catering I highly recommend T-Dubbs. You'll definitely get enough bank for you buck and it SO delicious.

We will not be ordering from Saffron ever again.
author: Alli M.

description:
I'm not sure what these guys are saying, but Ziad (a.k.a. The man behind the counter) is very friendly and helpful.  Not only do you get a mouthful of yummies and a delicious drink to wash it all down with, but you get cute tidbits about the history of the food and how they are made.

;-)  Great food for good price.  Always satisfied at this place.

P.S. I know Mediterranean is served, but If you ever try the french fries with Aioli (Balsamic/Lemon), you'll probably not want to have french fries anywhere else.
author: K S.

description:
One of the best falafel and hummus wraps I've ever had.  The bread was warm, toasty and delicious.  The hummus was creamy.  The falafel was perfectly seasoned and not over fried.

Friendly and quick service and reasonably priced.

The atmosphere is also pretty awesome.
author: Mack D.

description: Do you want that mediocre shawarma sandwich to be spicier? Well then you have to get up and pay 50 cents! It's not that I can't afford it, but after the service is so bad, getting nickel and dimed for something that EVERY other restaurant in SF gives you for free is what will prevent you from ever coming back.
author: Guillermo T.

description:
Really 3.5. 

Pretty dead on a weekday night. Saffron looked like it could be hopping with SOMA folk during lunchtime, but it was deserted for dinner. We did notice a few to go order being assembled so we weren't scared to try it. Plus yelpers had rated it high enough to worth a visit after our REI run. 

The SO (significant other) ordered a shrimp kebab platter, I ate a chicken kebab sandwich, and an order of tzatziki between us. It's really hard to resist the yogurt sauces when eating Mediterranean food.  His was pretty tasty, mine was mediocre but had a nice spicy sauce, and the yogurt sauce was fabulous. The sauce did seem to be a bit overpriced but the quantity was much larger then we possibly could eat in one meal. 

The interior is nice and clean with a variety of tables to sit at. High low, cushy, sturdy etc. 

I recommend  the mint lemonade!  Not sure how often this place will be frequented, but it's worth a shot if you're in the area.
author: Tina P.

description:
EDIT:
Today I went to Saffron 365 for the first time since writing my original review.  I guess these guys are reading yelp, because the owner spoke to me about my review.  In length and detail.  While I was with a external consultant on a business lunch.

Obviously I had a bad day, and was pretty upset when I wrote my review.  And obviously I upset the ownership here.  And I guess they were successful.  I am changing my review.  They have owned a business before.  And they are improving their service.  And they are reading Yelp, so I guess we have some power.

But you know what, I don't think I am ever going back there again.  The person I was there at lunch with couldn't believe I was spoken to like that.  I apologized several times.  And you know what, I am actually sorry.  But it still felt unprofessional to me.  And I am frankly afraid to return.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:

I don't believe the people who own this place have ever owned a restaurant before.  

How can I tell?

Well, I was sitting here with some coworkers for quite awhile a few weeks ago, and we had a lot of time to analyze the place.  The service is slow, bordering on god-awful slow.  The food comes out in an obscure order that seems to favor eating in over taking out, which makes sense if you want a large group of take out people sitting around in your restaurant.  There seems to be too little space on the grill, and too much space between stations to be efficient.  Watch the guys at Truly Med on 16th & Valencia and then watch these guys and you'll see exactly what I mean.  The difference is, the people who own this place designed these stations themselves.

Then there is the woman who works the counter, who I suspect may be the owner.  She has, dare I say, the oddest customer service of any owner operator I have dealt with.  She will tell every person who orders take out that the kebab's take 12 minutes and the falafel takes 6, pushing people to get the falafel.  The last time I made this choice, and got the falafel, it took at least 15 minutes, and someone who ordered after me got their kebab in 10.  Which pissed off everyone in our group, cause we had all come for kebab and left with falafel.

The only redeeming quality of the place is that the food is actually decent.  The veggie kebab is really tasty, and the falafel is, in fact, decent as well.  

But seriously, I would order ahead and avoid the anguish.
author: Steve S.

description: Superb food!!! Never dreamed a chicken kebab could have so much flavor. The only reason I don't give this 5 stars is that the atmosphere was lacking. Seems that this is best a lunch or weekend dining option.
author: Karen J.

description: Loved my first experience. My boyfriend and I called our order in without ever actually stepping foot in the restaurant. The guy working was really nice and helpful. Not only that, but once we got home, tasted the food and loved every bit of it. We ordered the lamb shwaerma with the hummus, baba ganoush and tzatziki. You could tell it was all made fresh and it made our first time eating their food that much better
author: Mogi D.

description: Food is excellent and affordable.  I discovered this during the day and then had a small party here at night -- everyone loved it.  I pre-ordered the food -- lots of appetizers, grilled meats, vegetables, and pita.  Everybody raved about the food and service, so it was a great success.  The baba ganoush is not to be missed, the meat eaters loved the grilled meats and the vegetarians loved the grilled vegetables and all the dips.  The saffron rice pudding is unbelievably delicious, as is the Turkish coffee. Parking at night and on Saturday is a breeze.
author: Kate C.

description:
Excellent wraps and attentive service!
We came here for lunch on Saturday and had the lamb shawerma and chicken kebab wrap, both were tasty and flavorful.  We saw him prepare the meal and he used fresh ingredients-always a plus!
The decor is nice and we liked that they had beer & wine too.  We enjoyed a Stella and Pilsner Urquell ( one of my hubby's favorites ) and it was a good accompaniment to the meal.  Looking forward to returning. ;-)
author: Lizete S.

description: My favorite after work stop for tasty middle eastern food. I call Ziad and he has my order ready in a few minutes. It's always delicious.  I particularly love the Shawarma plate, chicken kebab over salad, fresh soup and DELICIOUS turkish delight!!!  I could eat there every night.
author: Susan T.

description:
This place is really interesting. From the front it looks like a deli type of Mediterranean eatery but when you walk in, it has a huge space in the back with couches for seating. I don't know what to make of the interior. It's like it can't make up it's mind between a cafeteria'ish lunch spot to a nicer evening dinner spot. 

Anyways it's all about the food. The Lamb Shwarma was good. The place on 16th in the Mission was still better and close to half the price. The pluses of this place are that there aren't too many nearby Mediterranean places in the area and it's convenient to go or eat there. It's a little over priced but with the exception of Starbucks, all the restaurants are on that little section of businesses. 

We'll probably go back when we're craving a Shwarma but too lazy to drive to the Mission.
author: Hyung L.

description: Had a great meal here tonight.  Food was WONDERFUL, and the server could not have been more helpful despite the fact that we ordered in 37 stages (Now could we have tea?  Now could this other person in our party have a lemonade?  Now could we have a beef wrap we didn't order before? Now can we have a to go order?)  Food was terrific.  *Loved* the lamb Shawarma.  We parked right in front.   Had a large party so we sampled many dishes - all received great reviews from our group.  Have the mint lemonade - it was great!
author: Carrie M.

description:
yummy potato pancakes!!
had those with rice and hummus.. all pretty good
was in the area for the techcrunch hackathon, so this place was convenient. 
not a place i would go out of my way to return to, but not a bad option if i ever happen to be nearby. place seemed to be getting a steady stream of orders, so seems popular with locals!
3 stars .. A-OK seems to be a pretty good descriptor for my experience at this place!
author: Aditya M.

description:
I went to Saffron with my friends last night for dinner and found it...enjoyable.

Place is very large and completely empty on a Monday night, so the 6 of us had the whole place to ourselves :).  I'm pretty sure the joint wasnt built to be a restaurant, kind of resembles a furniture store?...but that means it feels clean and comfortable!

It's a one man show -- the owner is pretty nice but was not too amused as the 6 of us bombarded him with question after question about the ingredients, fat content, substitution options, etc...lol.  It's hard to please 5 health conscious girls (+ me...who'll eat anything).

Options were limited, but ingredients were fresh and decently tasty.  The meat in my swerma sandwich was tender...but again, nothing exciting.  FYI -- hot sauce cost 75 cents extra!

They do have a good expresso machine there, so after ordering a Turkish Coffee and hating it (it resembles a shot of expresso, full of grind *patoo*)... I was abe to get my latte fix. 

I think I'd like it way more as a lunch spot.
author: Kendra W.

description:
Loved this unassuming spot in the heart of Showplace Square. The food was great - my friend totally enjoyed her falafel platter, and I thought my chicken kebab wrap was superb. I especially liked how they barbecued the kebab (no excess oil here) and filled the wrap with hummus. All this was dished up with friendliest of service, and we ate our meal at one of the low tables that featured pillows to sit on instead of chairs. A nice twist on the overall modern environment.

Prices were a bit above your average takeout Mediterranean ($9 - $14), but considering the quality of the food, service and environment, I felt it was well worth the expense.
author: Jason B.

description:
Went on a lunch date here recently.

I went for the lamb shwerma sandwich which comes with the traditional lamb carved off the giant skewer, their hot sauce and some bits of potato and dressing rolled up in lavash bread.  I had them hold the onion on mine.  The sandwich was pretty good -- the hot sauce not as hot as I like so I would ask for double hot sauce next time.

I also ordered the side of baba ganoush ($5) and a side of fries ($4).

The baba ganoush was ok -- a little more gelatinous than I like but nice flavor and went well with the hot pita it arrived with.

The hand cut fries were out of this world.  I would say they rival the fries sold by that Frjtz place.  Delicious, hot, large cut chunks of perfectly fried potatoes that came with a delicious (mustard?) aioli.  This was my favorite part of the lunch.

The food that I tried here at lunch hour was top notch but somewhat pricey for lunch.  It came out to over $30 for two people after food, tax and tip.  But I'd like to come back.  It would have been a reasonably priced dinner.
author: Spicy T.

description: Not enough meat in the shawerma, charged $3 (!) for extra tzatziki sauce, and orders take days.
author: Rich L.

description: Just had the mannaesh plate.  So delicious and light; perfect for after a 2-hour Thai massage!
author: Kameron H.

description:
Bought the ~$6 falafel...was told there was a MINIMUM CHARGE of $8. Reluctantly I accepted because I didn't know my rights. Now, from my research, apparently I should be reporting them to my card company and getting them in trouble, because they are violating their agreement with the card company. Before I do that, however, I want to go talk to their manager. 

This is just not ok to do as this type of business. Now I don't want to eat there (despite the fact that the food is good), and I'm posting here to complain about it. Unfortunately the one time ~$1.50 they made off that minimum is going to cost them probably at least 2 $6.50 meals repeat business a week from me, and the business of everyone that listens to me when I warn them about my experience.
author: Casey P.

description:
This is a good place to pick up a fast, inexpensive, relatively healthy dinner/lunch, when you don't feel like cooking. The food is good, the portions are large and the menu is pretty extensive. 

We like the schawerma sandwich and dolmas. The only thing I have been truly unhappy with from S685 is the "rice pudding." It's a kind of bland, firm, gelatinous substance that isn't particularly sweet or creamy or resemble rice and/or pudding in any way. 

Overall, I'm just glad to have an inexpensive Mediterranean place in my neighborhood.
author: rachel m.

description:
3.4 stars. We were starving. Originally, we aimed to go to Holy Grill because I've been wanting to try that place and we were in a burger mood, they are closed on weekends! Boo.

Saffron was really good, fast, fresh, sour lemony flavor, hot food, busy, but not too crowded to enjoy ourselves.

I think the only downside for this place is the price. The chicken kebab plate cost a whopping $17 (I'm pretty sure this was the price, I know it wasn't cheap). This is a serve your own utensils and tables type of place. Tis good, yet saffron doesn't come cheap.

The amount of food per plate was fantastic, I guess you pay for the amount, right? Right. Service was pretty good. I want to go back and will keep it in my phone, yet the price will make me think a few times before choosing it.
author: Lorrie N.

description:
Very, very delicious Mediterranean food.  Expensive, but delicious.

Oh, I love this place.  If it was reasonably priced, I would come here all the time when I decide to go out for lunch.  It's healthy, it's delicious, it's never crowded, it's great.

The lamb shawerma is GREAT, and the combo plate is awesome.  I LOVE the moujadarra (bulgar wheat and sauteed onions), the falafel, and the tzadziki.  The pita and hummas are also good.  When I come here, I usually come with a friend and we share the lamb shawerma plate and the 3-appetizer plate.  Eat with your hands.

DELICIOUS!

OMG the baklavah....VERY good.

The guy who is here for lunch is not very friendly, and doesn't really excel in the customer service department, but just don't expect anything more than someone taking your money and giving you food and you won't be disappointed.
author: Matt L.

description:
It's always nice to see an office-worker lunch spot that offers lots of couch and floor-cushion seating, as if daring people to kick back for a bit and enjoy their lunch.  Nobody was taking them up on it, but next time, I'm totally doing it.

Jury's still out on the food.  I had a falafel wrap which was ok but in retrospect the veggie kebab wraps looked much more enticing...perhaps I was scared off by the 10-12 minute cook time.

Service is attentive and they have a lot of interesting though pricey mint drinks.  (In fact, priciness in general is the one flaw here).

So, all in all, I'm intrigued but not yet sold on Saffron.  I'm sure to be here again though, so I expect my next visit will make or break things.
author: Wes M.

description:
Okay, I respect this place even more.

They sent my friend an apology and an explanation so I will give them their deserve star-age.

Like I said, their shawarma (haha! yes I know how to spell it now!) was still out of this world (I actually recently tasted one from a 5 star hotel... I missed Saffron's shawarma plate oh so dearly). So yess. Hopefully, They won't run into the same snags again because I can see Saffron becoming a huge hit to everyone!
author: Gabe R.

description:
This place is clean, quiet, lots of places to sit, really great staff, and delicious food!!!

What else is there to say?!

I've eaten here twice now, once I ate in, and once to go.

This place is great if you want to catch up with a friend you haven't seen in awhile!!!  There isn't loud music or really loud kitchen noises to compete with...  Awesome....

Again, the staff is great.  The gentleman working there isn't over-the-top, which I actually prefer.  He's kind and patient, and as I watched him prepare our falafel sandwiches, I realized he is fantastic at making falafel sandwiches!!!

The falafel are really good, and my half-Lebonese boyfriend is very critical of falafel....  and HE liked them!!!

I also recommend the mint lemonade...  i want a gallon of it.

Prices aren't too bad either.

Go there now!
author: Jess R.

description:
Excellent food, very tasty Middle Eastern dishes that included a few vegetarian choices. The hummus was not the usual oil and garlic stuff served at many other places but had a good amount of sesame tahini. Roasted vegetables have a delicious dry rub. 
The cafe is set up as more of a "lunch-type" place wherein one orders from a counter and then chooses a table. However on Saturday night the waiter came to our table. My party of 3 and were the only active clients, though one woman sat at a table reading a book--sort of what you'd see at a cafe.
author: Francois T.

description:
My coworker said it was not so great but I tried it anyway. There's not much around 8th & Townsend so my choices are limited as far lunch.
She was right. My lentils were way too salty, even for me.
My chicken kebob was not cooked all the way. Besides that, it wasn't terrible but not worth the $13 and the ridiculously long wait. This place has a lot of potential but the slow service not yet refined menu need some work.
author: Rebecca R.

description:
Ambiance - quite cute. Low tables on one side, with large, warm- colored pillows on the floor.  

Food - I had the Meze platter.  I chose the Falafel, Hummus and a side of Chicken Kabobs with Flat Bread.  All very good.  My hubby and our friend both has the Lamb Shewarma and they both liked it.  

Prices - Affordable. Good bang for your buck. 

Service - The manager's tone was a bit brash and condescending (minus one star), but I guess that's fine when the restaurant set-up is more cafeteria style.
author: Clarice V.

description:
I stumbled upon this yummy establishment a few months back, while waiting for tha 10 bus.
I had a Falafel Wrap and Baklava. I could live on Baklava, and it did not disappoint.

There is not a ton of options of places to eat near this part of town, so I was glad to remember they were here while seeking a place for a quick meeting.

My friend Diana and I got a combo of sorts where you could pick 3 sides. We chose Baba Ganoush, Hummus, and their Homemade Fries... MMM!  

I washed it down with a Mint Lemonade (tre Unique!) and she a turkish coffee.

I will surely return. Next time I am trying their Gaz (Nougat w/pistachios & rose water).
author: Kellie P.

description: Love this place!  My wife and I come here pretty regularly - everything is delicious but our favorites are the schwarma and dolma. From two people who love Mediterranean, we think this place is delicious!
author: Justin S.

description:
I live and work in a loft around the corner from 685. There's not been a problem with finding local lunch fare when I'm so inclined, but the number of  dinner spots in a two block radius has been zero. Until now.

As others have observed, the lunch lines are often out the door (ah, the first week before 685 became known) and for good reason. The menu is not duplicated anywhere in the immediate area and the food is well prepared. So far, at dinnertime, there's no wait at all. Not surprising, considering the techies flooding the place at lunch seem to be home for dinner.  

Some of the food is displayed cafeteria style, so if you're not sure of what to order, pointing is a popular option. This presentation may not help the first impression of ambiance, but many of the tables are around the corner and out of sight.

Service is friendly--the lunchtime order taker knew my name on the second visit--, the ambiance warmish--love the low rise tables--and the food quite good. My personal favorite is the mojjadara, lentils topped with caramelized onions; this is comfort food to me and 685 does it well. Make it a third of your meza plate and lunch is $7 plus beverage. 

The lamb shawerma is excellent; I just finished the $11.50 Shawerema Plate and found it warm and filling. More than I would eat for lunch and certainly more than I'd pay for lunch, but just fine for dinner.  Dessert-wise, the konafa is excellent and the sesame cookies tasty. Try the pomogranite spritzer when the weather gets warmer; right now, you can't go wrong with the mint tea or spiced cocoa. 

Welcome to the 'hood, Saffron 685!
author: Lance H.

description:
Mediocre food.  Incredibly rude person behind the counter who refused to add a little more sauce to my falafel.  $8 minimum credit card order, when a falafel is $7.12.

The guy in front of me said he wouldn't be back.  I think I'll be doing the same.
author: Chris P.

description: The wraps are great.   The food is good and fresh overall.  The guy who works at the counter, the owner I presume, is rather unfriendly though and really needs to work on his customer service skills.  That being said, it's a good place to get quick good food.
author: Paul A.

description:
Update for 2008: I've gotten lunch here 30+ times over the past year, typically one of their delicious wraps. They are a finely tuned machine at this point. The owner / head cook is a nice guy, appreciates his customers and is super committed. Still not a fan of the inoffensively blah atmosphere, but this place works without it. A great option for fresh and reliably good Mediterranean food.

Original review:

This place seems to have a bit of a bad (w)rap so to speak. But I think it's a perfectly fine lunch option for the neighborhood. I'm no falafel/shawarma/kebab connoisseur but they seem pretty solid. Tasty and healthy and pretty reliable. I regularly stop in when I'm in the mood for not-burgers/Pazzo.

When they first opened I remember my coworkers complaining about the wait. But if you think about it the same is true for every other place. Pazzo and Holy Grill sometimes make you wait 20+ minutes and crank out orders non-sequentially*. You just notice it more here because the open kitchen is right in front of you so you can scrutinize the two guys behind the counter and play armchair manager. Anyway, I go slightly after the main rush so I haven't experienced much of a wait at all lately.

And the people are really nice. They even brought my order over to me while I was browsing next door the other day.

Don't know if I'd go for dinner though... the atmosphere in the back seems a little strip mallish. Well, I guess it is in a strip mall.

*Obviously I'm in geeky work mode right now.
author: Tom L.

description:
Went with a friend who's married to a Turkish woman and he knows his Mediterranean food.  We both ordered  the pleasantly surprising Lamb Shawerma.   Nice service.  Somewhat pricey.  

Definitely nice decor with pillows on the floor at some tables.  

A great option for this area.  Will definitely make this a regular lunch spot.
author: Curtis C.

description:
Ok, so I'm really not a big fan of giving not so great reviews.  But Im Im less of a fan of over priced food.  

Are you serious? 9 bucks for that little "sandwich wrap"?? I thought they would be a good size..but no...they are small for what you pay for. I really have NO problem paying 9 bucks for a good wrap, if its big!! 

My friend also ordered the chicken wrap, but she cannot eat hummus, so she had to order hers without, leaving it very dry.  She wanted just a very small side of the yogurt sauce to dip it in, so it would not be so dry.  FOUR bucks for a little side of the yogurt sauce.  She didn't want a whole DISH - just a side. Dude...seriously?? (and it takes them like 5-8 minutes to wrap one little thing- quite the technique - let me tell ya. Get a clue from the local burrito wrappers. They'll get that thing to ya in 30 seconds flat!) 

Food had good flavor and their couches are sweet - just a bit too pricey for what you get and a little slow.
author: Jenn T.

description: One of my favorite go-to places to get a lamb shawarma, tabbouleh, and a Turkish coffee. You can tell the owner is meticulous by the way he lines up his soda cans, so speaks volumes to the quality of the food he serves.
author: Matt K.

description:
their desserts are good.  especially the konafa - it's shredded filo like pastry with cheese & orange blossom water and pistachio's on top. YUM!

the hot cocoa is good too, it's spiced with cardamom.

I have to try their french fries with saffron or balsamic aioli.  update soon.
author: kulas a.

description: My partner and I came in at happy hour to grab a quick bite. After ordering some dolmas and tabouleh the guy at the counter assumed we would be taking it to go. When we said no he awkwardly / rudely stated that he couldn't seat us due to a reservation. Fast-forward an hour later... still empty. Although the food may have been palatable the service was not.
author: David C.

description: Great food. Really liked the falafel. Reasonable prices. Very clean and fun atmosphere. Good place for lunch.
author: DeeJay M.

description:
This is one of the better Mid-Eastern restaurants in the city.

- Moroccan spiced hot cocoa
Don't miss this. Deliciously flavored with cardamom

- Turkish Delight
These delicately flavored, gelatin type of candy that reminded me of a pate de fruit that are rolled in powder. Several flavors come with an order: green cardamom, pink rose water, orange water. lemon and a brown sqare that tasted like molasses.  

- Konafa

This pretty, tasty, buttery dessert of orange shredded pastry sprinkled with chopped green pistachios on a cheese base and flavored with orange blossom water is made in-house. 

- Manaesh
The manaesh is house-made bread that looks like a pizza and is  topped with olive oil & za'atar. I liked it.

I'll be back to try this more at this great new restaurant.
author: Rworange X.

description: No Mellow Yellow! This place had the rudest worker EVER! Like the soup nazi, we were astounded how overly nasty this guy treated us. He basically tried to talk us out of ordering food there, wouldn't let us sit down to eat in an almost empty restaurant, wouldn't give us a cup of water,  wouldn't give us chili sauce for our falafel...and even asked us if we were "from the East Bay?". Who does this? What crap!!! Boycott this place if at all possible! Underwarmed food, crappy attitude. Too horrible for words. Never again.
author: anne s.

description: Great place for lunch!  They are quick, convenient, friendly and fresh.  I love the lamb shawerma and falafel wrap as well as the mediterrarean combo plate & kebab salads.  The latkes are good too.  I try to venture out on the menu more but can't seem to shake my favorites so far.  Another plus...I usually find metered parking avaliable on the street!
author: Martin I.

description:
This new Mediterranean place has fantastic food.  I got the Meza plate, which is a sampling of any three sides or salads.  Everything was really tasty and it was great value as well.  
I loved the decor in the place.  It is very airy and the tables are spread out.  There are a few low tables with cushions at the back.  

There were a few downsides to the place:  firstly, while the service was fast, they forgot several things we ordered.  We had to go up to the counter to remind them we had ordered drinks and a couple of side dishes.  Also, the desserts were not that great.  If it weren't for these two things, I would have given it 4 stars.

I would definitely go back for the main dishes-yum!
author: Emma M.

description:
I actually like this place because the food and the menu as a whole is interesting.  I'm hesitant to give it more than three stars though because this place still has a few kinks to work out.

First, what's good:  the food is very flavorful and it's great to have mediterranean cuisine in the neighborhood.  The falafel has a decent crunch.   The fried potato cakes are very tasty.  The falafel wrap is filled with a nice variety of ingredients and then it's briefly toasted on the outside, which I like a lot.  Customer service at the cash register has improved in tone since they first opened.

Not so good:  as others have mentioned, prices are on the high side.  I understand they are in a brand new building and probably have high rent, but it does preclude me from eating here more often.  While, on the whole, I enjoy the falafel wrap, for some reason the little strips of eggplant they put in there had tough skins one time, which I had to pick out.  Finally, every time I go, there's something about the atmosphere that's not warm and welcoming.  Perhaps its the lack of natural light in the back.  Perhaps its the doors being always wide open.  Maybe if one or two of the staff was more conversant with the customers, that would do the trick.

This place has potential to be a really great lunch spot.  I'll be back, but maybe not for a few weeks.
author: Mason W.

description:
I love it here.  It's the perfect pre and post workout meal.  My favorite time to come is around 5:00 when I'm getting off work and about to go to the gym on 9th and Brannan.  I'm suprised their dinners are not busier since this is such good, light, flavorful food.  Lunches are crazy with lines out the door, so beware.
Lots of vegetarian options for all you veggie's out there.  Try their veggie kabob plate.  It rocks.  Fresh eggplant, squash, onion, tomatos, and mushrooms grilled to perfection.  There are many places that serve Greek and Mediterranean food, but Saffron 685 blows them away.  Nowhere else in SF can you get this quality of food for their low price point and beautiful enviroment.
author: Vang L.

description: I came here with my coworker for a Monday afternoon lunch.  The place was pretty empty with only two other tables having customers.  This was pleasing to see because I was pretty hungry and hoping to get my food quickly.  I had the Lamb Shawerma and my coworker had a Falafal Plate.  I would rate both dishes at good, but nothing spectacular.  My lamb was cooked perfectly and my wrap had the right amount of moistness.  I really dislike dry Mediterranean sandwiches.  I thought that the tabouleh and tahini salad on the Falafal plate were very flavorful.  Overall, I think this place is good, there is nothing extraordinary about the food but it's good nonetheless, which in my book deserves a 3 star rating.  I would recommend this place for weekday lunches.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
The food is average....very average.

Also, the review below is correct, the guy behind the bar has the personality of a dolma.  I have been here twice and experienced the same level of service both times.

Both times I have been there the place has been totally dead, which is strange because the surrounding restaurants were busy.  Anyway, if you're starving and only interested in Mediterranean food, then take a try.  But don't expect to be blown away.
author: Vanessa Z.

description: If I could sit all day and stuff my face with their red pepper dip and beet root salad (with a swig of water every 15 minutes to clear my palate), I would.
author: Carina M.

description: As we know, the new code work for Middle Eastern Food is now "Mediterranean" so as not to scare mainstream patrons off. The codeword sometimes can confuse people as one may expect Greek food, Italian food, etc. This place is MIddle Eastern. That means falafel, chicken and beef kebabs, hummus, etc is offered. Now, the fact that a rude Ukranian server with no customer service skills is your point person can be a problem. However, ultimately, when your chicken kebab sandwich wrap has one small piece of chicken with potato and tahini sauce as filler, you should be concerned. Especially at a ridiculous price of $9. The sandwich wrap was cold, the service was rude, and when I complained that I only received a small chunk of chicken kebab, the Ukrainian cashier/service just shrugged. Now that's more Soviet than Middle Easter/Mediterranean. What a bust this place is.
author: Raffi M.

description:
Finally!! I have finally found a place in SF that serve decent Tzatziki (or as this restaurant spells it: Tzazekee). Well it only took about 2 years to find it.

I had a quick late lunch with Tzatziki, Pita bread and Pomegranate spritzer and a few nibbles of the Chicken Kebab Plate - it was all good. I'll be back that is for sure.
author: Sofia K.

description:
After a bit of furniture shopping, I was famished. I needed to eat STAT. Saffron 685 was just around the corner and I am glad to say it saved my life. There wasn't very much around for us to choose from in terms of places to eat. So going in to Saffron 685 seemed like a no brainer. 

THEY TAKE VISA CARD.  Though this may not be apparent when you first walk through the store. It is indeed an establishment that caters to those who never carry cash.

I ordered the Chicken Kebab dish. It was grilled and came out wrapped in a breaded / pita shell. I thought it was absolutely delicious.  It could have been that the taste was a direct reflection of how hungry I was. Though this could be a possibility, I will have to say that my meal was yummy and I won't doubt my hungry stomach.

.
author: Jane D.

description:
I have only had the falafel wrap here so I probably need to try more items to get a full picture of this spot. The first time my falafel was pretty good. A little bland but okay. The second time I ordered from this place my falafel was really bland. The hummus and falafel were really underseasoned. I was disappointed. 

I love Mediterranean food so I have to give this place another chance. There are limited ethnic food lunch options in this neighborhood so I hold out hope that it was just an off day. Seems like Yelpers like the meat offerings for the most part so I'll try something different next time.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Ate here once, don't really feel like going back.

Lamb kebab was dry and the menu selection, paltry.

Feel bad because they are one of the only restaurants around this neighborhood that is not owned by the Mission Bay Foods Empire.

If you like it, keep going. If you haven't been, try it once, but you won't be missing anything if you don't go.

(And I can't believe about what happened to Steve S.!)
author: Rey T.

description:
Finally a decent place to eat around this area!  The prices are fairly reasonable, the service is not bad either.  It's not one of those sit down and order places.  Rather, you order at the counter, give your name and wait at the table.  Then one of their employees will call your name and bring your food to the table.  

We ordered the falafel sandwich and the lamb kebab sandwich along with a pistachio baklava.  The lamb kebab sandwich was quite tasty, although it could have been better with a bit more seasoning.  But overall, it was very refreshing.
author: Selene K.

description: Saffron 685 is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  The atmosphere is comfortable and the staff friendly.  The food is clean and tasty and the flavors keep me coming back for more.  The salmon plate is one the best I have had anywhere in town.  Plenty of choices for vegetarians and meat lovers alike.  You wont regret trying this place for your mediterranean cravings.
author: Nikki P.

description: There is a reason why this place is empty after lunch.  If you order dinner it is likely that you are having the lunch they made earlier reheated in a microwave.  But the food is still not that bad.. the main reason why people should avoid this place is the horrible service.  I seemed to blow the mind of the guy working there when I asked for a plastic bag and a napkin for my to go order.  I doubt this place is going to survive another year in its current state.
author: Amit P.

description: I've been coming to Saffron for years, since the company I work for moved across the street.  What keeps me coming back in particular is the shawarma, whichever dish you order it in.  I also order from them whenever I need catering for the office, and in either context, the food is always exceptional and the service is personal.  It is definitely the best restaurant in the area, so when I don't get my lunch there it means I've brought my lunch from home.
author: Marie R.

description:
I finally got away from my boss for an hour a day for the past two weeks, and chose to retreat to Saffron.  I loved the decor, the people are super friendly, and because they are one of our customer's too there was extra special attention paid to me.  Everyone who works there is observant to customer needs and seems to read your mind when you need anything at all during the meal.

Turkish Delight is delicious, as is the cucumber salad, the pom spritzer...aw, heck, EVERYTHING there is good.  Allow more time for kebabs and prawns.
author: Jo S.

description: Falafel wrap was super dry and tasteless.  Service was extremely slow.  Charged me almost $5 for yogurt that I asked for since the wrap was so dry. Will never go back.
author: Cheeks C.

description:
I've been dinning at Saffron 685 for years, as an admirer of middle-eastern cuisine and also a 1/4 Syrian descendant I find this place quite honest to its heritage. Coming from a country of immigrants with the largest Syrian-Lebanese community outside those two countries, more than 6 million and their direct descendants, I believe I have the knowledge to elaborate over the subject.
 
I've tried their falafel sandwiches, shish kabob plates, humus, baba ghanoush, they are all delicious and above all the ingredients are always fresh. The shish kebob is served the way I like it - grilled with lemon in it, where I came from the Lebanese grill with lime - even better. But I've noticed lately the shish kebob plate is being served in smaller portions. I love the humus prepared there, they don't add garlic and you can actually taste it the way it's supposed to be not like other middle-eastern restaurants in the city where they add tons of it - a trick done to disguise the stale taste of days seating in the fridge. Usually I eat my hummus traditionally, soaked in olive oil, I always have to ask for it, they avoid serving that way because like salt you add at your own discretion. The baba ghanoush, my favorite, it's smoked to perfection with the right amount of tahini, I can eat a whole side order (fairly sized) with pita bread in one seat. The tabbouleh salad is really well balanced, I always judge on that, if they cannot get it right, mind as well shut down the business.  
 
The owner has been venturing lately into soups, I find them unnaptizing, they are too thick (puree style) to my taste. I think he is trying to cater to the American palate - they love porridge soups. Once I tried the red bell peper lentil soup, but the owner had stepped out for couple of hours and his staff served the soup luke warm - I was already skeptical, you can imagine my reaction.
 
I noticed last time I was there (a week ago) they have torne down the menu from the wall, I asked why, and found out they are reformulating the entire menu. Let's wait and see what kind of delicacies will be coming out of their kitchen - I bet they will be tasty, the chef/owner is well versed in the kitchen.
 
Regarding the individual menu, the lay-out needs improvement. All the dishes are crammed on one side of the menu with plenty of room on the other side just for beverage and dessert. Honestly, not even with reading glasses I could discerned the lines, and the poor choice of red ink made it worse to read.
 
As for the ambience, the place offer all sorts of seating and tables, my favorite are the lower tables and cushions in the back. It's probably the most clean restaurant in the city, you can eat off the floor, the owner always display with pride its 100 points SF Health Department gave to the establisment - it's been that way for years. They also have a good selection of ambient music playing at all times, jazz, blues, bossa-nova, never heard though classic and/or contemporary middle-eastern music - I wonder why ? 

I might be reviewing this venue again later to five star - it will depend what surprises in the future they will have fresh out of the oven.
author: Marcello C.

description:
Many of the reviews here are accurate.

In short: relatively short wait time, good food.  Cost too much.

Saffron 685 employees:  We can't afford to eat there regularly!

I've ordered lunch here, on average once every two weeks, since they opened.  I enjoy their food.  I can't compare it with other mediterranean food.  Here's something I've noticed over time:

I walk by Holy Grill to get here.  Holy Grill's packed, and this place is practically empty.  The ONLY reason I can think of is the price.  The woman at the counter (haven't seen her the past couple times) is overly / oddly friendly, and I know some customers might be turned off by that - but not enough to just not go / return after all this time.

I always order either the Lamb Schwerma or the Falafel wrap, because they seem to be the most cost effective.  I order them to go.

My coworkers never go to Saffron 685 because of the cost.  After reading the reviews here, I know it's not just us who feel that way.

I noticed that the quality has improved over time.  At one point, the falafel wrap was dry, and you could feel, carrying it out, that it was light.  A few weeks later, it was much heavier, and that's because they added more ingredients.

Although I enjoy the lack of crowd, I don't understand why they haven't lowered their prices or at least considered introducing one of those cards where you buy 10, get 1 at a reduced price, or even free of charge - it seems like they have potential to attract a lot more customers.  They don't have much competition - and I'd really like to be able to choose from more items on their menu, without spending half of my week's lunch budget in one day.
author: John B.

description: Sweet and simple. The food was good, service was fast, it's close by.
author: Teresa M.

description: Great little Mediterranean I actually found through Yelp! while I was in town.  We were the only patrons (late lunch) and the guy working was really friendly and helpful. We had a good spread of different things and, though a tad pricey feeling given then aura of the place, they were all very good.  If I were a local, I would definitely frequent (as much as I could afford).
author: Justin F.

description: What's their problem?  I had a short lunch window and dashed down here for food but left after 20 minutes of waiting - for a takeout chicken kebab wrap!  The sooner they go out of business and vacate, the better.  No wonder this place is virtually empty while every other place nearby has a line out the door.
author: Jan B.

description: Saffron is a find! Ziad makes beautiful soups and healthy Mediterranean delicacies. It's one of our favorite dinner spots. The kabobs are perfect, the seasoning on the salmon is fabulous, and the salads and sides are excellent. Wine by the glass available now, too. Super clean place, nice desserts. We've always found Ziad to be friendly and engaging, a really nice guy running a really good place.
author: Dave S.

description:
I work on the other side of the freeway from the Division traffic circle into which Townsend flows. One day, I decided to stop treating the freeway like an international border, and wandered over to check out the lunch options on the other side.

Saffron 685 was the first place I tried, and I've become a regular since. The owner is friendly and cares about the food (he makes his own shawarma, rather than buying shawarma-in-a-drum from a distro). It's not cheap, but this is San Francisco and in a new development; I'm sure the rent is eye-watering. The interior is warm and charming, and a very good use of a very industrial space. It can get a bit zoo-y at lunch (the only time I've had imperfect service there was during the lunch rush).

The mint lemonade is wonderful, too.
author: Christophe P.

description: The food here is exceptional for the price you pay. I especially recommend the lamb kebab and prawn kebab plates. All the food is prepared well, tastes fresh, and is very tasty. Unlike some of the reviews here, I find the owner of this one man operation to be very friendly and I find the service to be outstanding.
author: Zachary K.

description: This is a nice little lunch spot in my neighborhood.  I always order a chicken kebab wrap and some dolmas and I am set for the day.  They make everything fresh - which is a huge plus in my book.  Everything is great quality and the prices aren't too bad.
author: Cherlyn M.

description: Maybe this guy was having a bad day, but that's no excuse for treating customers like crap.  Actually being treated like crap would have at least acknowledged that I was a customer instead of completely ignoring me.  On top of that the food was bland and unsatisfying.  I ordered the chicken kabob salad, which had about as much flavor as a rice cake.  Based on similar reviews I am not alone in my opinion on the quality of food and service.
author: Roberto L.

description: Since I work in an isolated area of Mission Bay, there aren't too many options for restaurants to choose from.  You would think that all the restaurants would be great, but this one is only so-so for me.  I typically get the Lamb Kabab plate.  It's pretty good considering what it is, but over time, I've noticed the size of the kababs slowly shrinking in size.  I'm sure they are cutting their portions smaller, but come on!  The lemon wedges on the skewers are larger than the lamb at times!  The dolmas and the hummus have great flavor as well.  I just feel that for the price, you would expect something more filling.  You could easily spend $15-$20 and walk away thinking "eh, I've had better."
author: Mark P.

description: Wayne and I were here about a month ago and we were the only ones in the restaurant on a Saturday night. The food was very San Francisco priced but the quality was just too bland for my taste. All the flavor was served in side "salad" dishes that you could blend into your meal to your palate's liking, but to me that defeats the whole point of dining out. Only real perk: probably the best baklava in the Bay Area I've had the pleasure of eating.
author: Selina L.

description: I had ordered to-go a few times and dined in once at this restaurant because it's pretty close to where I live. Their service here is very good since they don't have many customers during weeknights. Their food are all freshly made, and my favorite is the Latkes. I agree that the interior needs more attention, but it is the perfect place to order to-go for dinner when you're feeling lazy!
author: Bee T.

description: This is a nice casual place with really fresh and tasty food.  I just got back from here having had their prawn kabab plate with a side of tzatziki, and it was very good.  The only strange thing is how deserted this place is in the evening.  I suppose that's just because of the area.
author: Robert P.

description: This seems like a very different lunch spot, with nice decor, spread out tables, and even some low tables and cushions to sit on at the back of the restaurant. Anyway, as some previous reviewers have noted this place is a little pricey especially the sides. Personally I wonder if they halved the size (and price) of the sides they might do a little better. Anyway, I just got a lamb shawerma sandwich which was excellent but I decided to drink water and forgo any sides. The sandwich was huge and full of lovely lamb, tomatoes, yogurt, I might have even got a little tzatziki. Anyway, it makes a change from the holy grill.
author: Karl L.

description: Love their shawerma wrap, worth 3+ stars, actually. Have had it both for lunch and dinner.
author: Kaj HeGe H.

description: This place is probably a 3.5 star join. I will round up since they are in my neighborhood! I've had the Falafel wrap and also the lamb shawerma wrap. Both were very good, better than other Greek style places I have tried in this area. My only knock is the pricing because this place is expensive. Other than that you will be pleasantly full after leaving!
author: John F.

description: I don't always order a falafel when I enter a Mediterranean place as I am a lamb lover. However, I just had their falafel sandwich today and it was the best I have had in recent memory. In addition, to the quality the service was delightful. I am going back soon.
author: Matthew S.

description: Great fresh homemade & authentic mediterranean cuisine. Try the grilled chicken and the lemon aioli (homemade) - it's the best. Super friendly service too. Yummy.
author: Raoul R.

description: The falafel plate was okay, but I found the falafel to be very hard and crunchy. I don't like it quite as browned/hard fried as they served it. I also thought the hummus was bland. My friends got the lamb schwarma and enjoyed it, so I will probably try that next time. The french fries were good and the balsamic dipping sauce that came with them was very good. As for the drinks, I had lemonade (decent) because they had diet pepsi but no regular pepsi. Um, what? Bizarre.
author: Kellie P.

description: It's nice to have a Mediterranean place so close to Potrero Hill. The food is made with fresh ingredients and not too heavy or greasy. The lamb plate is great and so are the shwarmas.
author: Oliver O.

description: Not the best Chicken Kebab sandwhich I've ever had, but not terrible. The inside of the place was nice and the people were friendly. Not the fastest service I've gotten.
author: Lacey R.

description: the salads are really great and fresh with nice citrus and spice notes but most of the meat I've tried isn't the best. The lamb, while flavorful is tough and the chicken tastes like it was loaded down with solution at the factory. oh and the falaffel is re- fried and rubbery with an acrid flavor. Truly Mediterranean on 16th smokes this place.. it's the small things like putting onions and tomatoes near the base of the meat spit soaking up the warm juices.. or how they grill the bread nice and crusty each time for the flat bread sandwich's..but the thing is that it's the only game in this part of town and by default it's a good choice. the price is right, the guy behind the counter is friendly and it's comfortable. ehh
author: Stephen G.

description: i went for lunch the other day and it pretty good.  the falaffel was very tasty and cooked perfectly.  The cucumber salad was delish and fantastic w/ the shawerma.  That shawerma sandwich itself was only okay.  the lamb was good, the skill w/ which the sandwich was made was great as well.  what i didn't enjoy was the hummus in the sandwich.  i thought it was a bit dry, like it needed a little more tahini and maybe some olive oil.  i'm willing to give it another go, since i live around the block, but i will ask for baba ganoush instead of hummus and see how it is.
author: David S.

description: The guy behind the counter has the worst attitude, which makes it a chore to go back there (and it would be so convenient since I live in the same building as this restaurant). Their falafel is dry anyway. I cannot recommend this place.
author: Corina M.

description: When you walk in, you'll notice right away that there is a lot of space.  The decor is pleasant and almost zen-like.  I ordered their Falafel and Hummus plate which was really good.  The salad and vegetable sides were refreshing with just the right amount of spices.  You get a good amount of food for the price you pay and the service is very friendly.
author: R B.

description: Love this restaurant and what a great space!  It's packed at lunch but it would be a perfect place to hold a birthday party for dinner.  A friend and I just went there for dinner and it was fantastic!  Fresh, high quality ingredients and reasonably priced.
author: Juliana X.

description:
There are many great places in Europe that offer Shawerma and kebab, London, Paris, Vienna and most cities in Germany are full of such great places. We were missing one here in San Francisco. Finally we have one. 
I live close by and have been to Saffron many time. The food is Delicious and staff are very friendly. If you go around lunch time you see how popular the place is. Dinner is great too, great place to have long conversation with friends and enjoy wonderful food.
author: Amir B.

description:
Saffron is unquestionably overpriced, but the food is really quite good.  I typically get the falafel plate, and I'm quite satisfied with it.  From general observation it seems that the plates tend to be a far better value than the wraps or any of the appetizers.

Ultimately, the most frustrating aspect is probably latke pricing: they are so ridiculously overpriced that I only get them about one in every ten visits.  Which, to be honest, is probably better in the long run!

A good spot for lunch, or really any time.
author: Patrick P.

description: I went to this place lots of times and every single time I enjoy it! I am a vegetarian and even though I found lots of great food to eat at Saffron like veggie wrap or meza plate! It is nice atmoshere, helpful staff and delicious food! Oh, and which is really, REALLY important for me- this place is VERY clean! So, I will definetely go back over and over again!
author: Yulia E.

description:
I found in love with this place!

Food: Flavorful, made with high quality ingredients and because everything is fresh and cooked to perfection, the menu advises that kebabs may take 10-12 min...Everything looks and smells delicious, the diner plates are generous and I would personally recommend the prawn kebab plate but don't hesitate to ask for recommendations. The sweets and fresh drinks are also a nice treat.
I ordered some items for a party and everybody loved the food!

Ambiance: Decorated with taste and feels warm and cozy. Good sound system without having the music killing you. Works well if you're alone, on a date, with friends or co-workers. You just have to choose what works best for you: the chairs/tables, sofas/tables or the floor pillows/low tables. The place is big and has large tables for groups.

And finally, everything is super clean!
author: Caroline B.

description: I went here after checking in for bay to breakers because it looked decent. The chicken in the kebab we bright red and raw. Pretty dam gross.
author: Jacob H.

description:
not bad...came here the other night for dinner and there was no one in there, except the guy behind the counter.  the wait was a little long seeing as how there was no one else in there, but it was worth the wait.  the food was fresh and delicious and the service was with a smile.

i'm glad i live close to here so i can grab some takeout!  try the mint lemonade...mmmm!
author: cindy c.

description: Had the lamb shawerma plate, and it was quite good!  The meat was delectable, I got the perfect amount of everything: hummus, rice, tabouli.  Love the decor, cushions in shades of red and orange, and low tables as seating.  Do wear the stretchy jeans, though.
author: M. H.

description: Good atmosphere, friendly staff, and a large portion size.  You'll pay more for the bigger portions, but it's proportional (150% the price for 150% the meal).  They have a good selection of food, more than your typical Mediterranean place.  Not an amazing amount that is vegan, but enough for me.
author: Nessie V.

description:
nummers!

the first time I tried Saffron I ordered the shawerma plate.  having been back a half-dozen times since, I still haven't ordered anything *but* the shawerma plate.  it's really that good.

I live nearby, so I have the luxury of eating at saffron during non-peak hours.  I've been in one time during the lunch crush -- and it can be pretty freakin' busy (for good reason).  best to side-step the crowd and go in a little later if you want to avoid the friction.

nice folks working here too.  it's a welcome addition to an area that needs more restaurants.
author: Mark B.

description:
Always reliable, the main guy that works there is quite nice and so are the people that work for him. 

I usually go for the Metza plate, 3 choices plus bread for 7 bucks. 
Can't go wrong. :)
author: Brendan A.

description: Ordered the lamb schwerma sandwich and dolmas. They were outstanding! Lunch was $38 + tip for three people, so not cheap but not bad. But well worth it!
author: Jared G.

description: Eh. It's ok. Totally hit or miss. The wait is LONG, the pricing structure makes no sense whatsoever ($6.50 for a falafel wrap but $4 for a side of fatoush salad?), but it's near work and the food is usually pretty good.
author: Emily E.

description: We live near by and love this place. WE find "the guy behind the counter" to be nice but most importantly interested in the quality of his food!  We recently held a large dinner here for about 20 people and MR. Z was so helpful in planning the menu, making sure we had the right amount of food and adding some nice extra touches. It is also great for kids (we had 6) as it is fun for them to sit on the cushions and eat at the low tables.  Favorites include the falafel (always fresh), lamb kebabs, shwarma and of course the always fresh baklava.
author: Tia L.

description: The wraps are a good deal! I especially liked the shawerma. The falafal wrap is delicious and vegetarian! You can't tell how big it is inside from outside. Nice atmosphere in the back.
author: Edward J.

description: I've eaten here a few times and it's solid Mediterranean fare. The lamb shwarma sandwich is my favorite (extra hot sauce, of course!). I also like the grilled chicken skewers and all the side salads, like hummus etc. and the konafa (sp?) dessert. Actually, I haven't had anything bad here. I hear it's quite busy at lunch time due to the office buildings surrounding it. I eat here in the evenings or on the weekends, and it's pretty quiet and mellow. Another good spot on a good block (see also Holy Grill).
author: Boss H.

description: I just got back from Saffron 685 and after finishing my chicken kabab wrap thought I would post my thoughts. This place is GREAT! The food is amazing and the restaurant itself has a great vibe with nice decor, high and low tables and pillows throughout. I've taken a group of coworkers and clients there in the past who all thought the food was delicious as well. (and the Hummus is to die for!) Always fresh, well-prepared, fabulous atmosphere - Saffron 685 gets my 5 stars!
author: Greg Ciro T.

description:
They have some of my favorite options for drink, like Reeds Ginger Ale and Pomegranate Spritzer made with Pomegranate Juice and club soda... The spritzer is $3.50 though.  The service was good but not the friendliest... are we in New York or something ? I will go here again though..Food was overall, tasty and healthy. 
See a video of the place @ http://sf-lunch.com/2008/02/12/saffron-685/
author: SF Luncher z.

description:
I eat here on average 1-2 times a week since the place opened, as I work nearby.

The food is always fresh and consistently tasty. The Hummus in particular is to die for - the owner has told me it is made fresh in-house every morning, and you can taste it.

The wraps and falafel are excellent, but if you are in the mood for a salad-style meal, you can't go wrong with the Mediterranean plate or the Manaesh plate - they are both to die for.

For desert the Baklava is also amazing - I think it is made there too.

The place gets a little busy during lunch, but there are extra staff then to help things move as quickly as possible. At other times, expect more personal attention from the friendly staff.
author: David K.

description: The food is decent for lunch, but the workers are extremely rude.  The food service is also poor - one orders and pays at the cafeteria-style counter and then sits at a table, awaiting food delivery.
